story:
Hey there DIY Supporters -

My name is Jeremiah Sammartano and I'm looking to get funds to get a new album recorded and released. I play a bluesy/Americana mix of music as Jeremiah and the Red Eyes and I've been touring and playing across the US and into the UK fairly regularly for the past few years. During this time on the road I've been writing and gathering songs and yes, several of these songs are about being on the road.  Now it's time to get them recorded and out to the world - and to hit the road.
For the new album, which is going to be called: These Motel Days, I'm asking for help with the sum of $3,000. This will cover the cost of the local studio time, getting CDs produced, a new batch of t-shirts with a new design, posters for upcoming tours in the new year (shows are already being booked and will continue to be booked), and some pay to the musicians helping me out. If I pass the $5,000 mark then I'll get a run of vinyl pressed up. As an indie and a DIY artist I'm always appreciative of any outside help.
I'm am looking forward to sharing this new album with everybody, and for helping out I do have some "specials" to share and pass along with different levels of contributions: demos of the album, older songs, the current t-shirt and the new one, postcards, prints of some of the photos that I have taken when traveling over these past years, house concert party - and of course, the new album.
If I don't happen to reach the desired goal, the album will still be completed - but it will just take a bit longer to be released. Right now I've set aside some time to record over this winter but if the goal isn't met it will be pushed back to the spring and then released ASAP.
A few years ago I was successful with a fundraising campaign to support a tour across the US. There was a lot to learn and those lessons have carried over to what I do now.  I enjoy the whole DIY thing and feel I do a good job of it - from writing and recording, to booking national and international shows and tours, to making posters and t-shirts. There is always so much to do and sometimes it's hard to stay focused - especially when you're on the road - but in the end I am able to get things done.
I'm thankful for whatever anyone can do to help get this record made. Contributing is great but also just passing along this information to someone else is helpful too.
thank you,
yours truly,
Jeremiah
Jeremiah and the Red Eyes

story:
Hi

Its been 17 years since I recorded "Still Standing", and I am ready to get back in the studio. I have so many songs I want to share with you, but need your help to put my new album "Talking to Trees" together properly.  Check out "BackRoom" from the album "Still Standing" here: https://1001sasongs.wordpress.com/2015/12/11/ba...

By buying a copy of the new album in advance, you can help me raise the funds needed for studio time, engineers, mastering etc. so I can record totally independently without record company influence :-)

I am asking you to help me raise $50 000. Sounds like a lot I know, but bear in mind the budget for the last Ellamental album was $350 000. I just want to do a beautiful album, and I want to do the songs justice, for me and for you, and doing it right means spending some money, quite a lot of it in fact.

Different contributions will get you different rewards, so be sure to check out the different Perks on the top right ---->

Everyone who contributes will receive a recording of "Bark: A Tree Story", featured in my Indiegogo intro and a digital download of the poster below: "Bark the Tree" and of course everyone will receive a gift download of my birthday gig on the 28th November (see pics of the farm venue in the GALLERY shortly), just as soon as we can edit the footage together in the week or two following ;-)

For those that don't know me, I leave it to Jannie van Tonder's summation of my career & the videos in the GALLERY, to tell you my story;

Tim Parr is a veteran of the South African music scene who has shared the stage with the likes of Hot House Flowers and Champion Jack DuPree. He started his musical career as a youngster in Joburg back in 1976, with the cult band Baxtop together with Larry Amos.

In the 80s he and his wife Heather Mac formed the band Ellamental. They recorded two albums and many singles for EMI Records and had several Number One hits in South Africa.

They relocated to Ireland in 1986 and spent seven years performing in Europe and USA.The head of the Warner Brothers in New York heard Ellamental live at the Marquee club in London and signed them up to do an album with Simply Red producer Stewart Levine, after which Ellamental supported Joan Baez at the Montreaux Jazz Festival in 1989.

Tim returned to SA and started the Zapdragons in 1994 which included Josh Hawks on bass (now with Freshly Ground). He released a solo album Still Standing in 1996, from which the single “If you Rush You Crush” reached No. 4 on 5FM SA, and the song “Still Standing” reached the charts in USA. Tim now lives in Cape Town and performs regularly at venues around the country.

So tell your friends, Tweet my Indiegogo campaign and post a link on your Facebook page etc, help me spread the word because every little bit helps, and the more people behind me, the better the album will be!

Love & peace
Tim

 the stage with the likes of Hot House Flowers and Champion Jack DuPree.

with the cult band Baxtop together with Larry Amos.
In the 80s he and his wife Heather Mac formed the band 
Ellamental. They recorded two albums and many singles for EMI Records 
and had several Number One hits in South Africa. 

They relocated to 
Ireland in 1986 and spent seven years performing in Europe and USA.The head of the Warner Brothers in New York heard Ellamental live
 at the Marquee club in London and signed them up to do an album with 
Simply Red producer Stewart Levine, after which Ellamental supported 
Joan Baez at the Montreaux Jazz Festival in 1989.

Tim returned to SA and started the Zapdragons in 1994 which 
included Josh Hawks on bass (now with Freshly Ground). He released a 
solo album Still Standing in 1996, from which the single “If you Rush 
You Crush” reached No. 4 on 5FM SA, and the song “Still Standing” 
reached the charts in USA. Tim now lives in Cape Town and performs 
regularly at venues around the country.


So tell your friends, Tweet my Indiegogo campaign and post a link on 
your Facebook page etc, help me spread the word because every little bit
 helps, and the more people behind me, the better the album will be!

Love & peace
Tim

story:
Who am I 

I am an entrepreneur that wants to offer musicians and venues a simple way to be booked. 
Origin of Idea

After trying to be a musician and being aware of the talent that exists, you can say that I am a  frustrated musician who wants everyone with an artistic talent to succeed; by helping them generate revenue.

Importance

Anyone can manage their bookings online with a simple platform that integrates tools that have already been developed by other companies.  

Solution

Jyngi is developed where musicians create a portfolio with their public posts on third party platforms, payment processors, and other services in the future...  

Many people would have loved to dedicate her/his life to creating art, a platform for everyones art is born.

We need to monazite talent or content created. 

What we need and what you get

We need $280.000 that are going to be invested in: marketing, 46%; development 23%; design, 8%; legal fees, 8%; and salaries, 15%.

Everyone with internet access and where money transfers are accepted, limited to countries where PayPal, Youtube, or Soundcloud is available initially; and where the legal system allows us to offer these services. Will be able to book musicians through Jyngi and be booked with us.  

Help us give an opportunity for talented individuals to be booked!

If we lack funds to reach our goal, we will keep on going with the project and allocate the resources with the percentages mentioned above.

How does it work?

Create a portfolio by connecting your public content  platforms such as Youtube and Soundcloud, you will be ranked based on user interactions, pay and be payed for bookings with PayPal.

Challenges 

The biggest challenge is to get venues or event organizer that are going to hire musicians; once they are interested in hiring musicians through Jyngi, more artists and more venues will register with Jyngi.
The backbone of the platform has already been built, the funds will be used mainly for marketing and to scale the business.
We are reaching out to venues that are going to attract great musicians and therefore attract more venues, creating a snowball effect.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you prefer to help in some other way different from contributing funds, please help us by sharing our crowdfunding link on social networks or with someone who might be interested in booking a musician; or simply by registering on our site with your Youtube or Soundcloud and telling us your #hashtag to look for your posts on Instagram.

story:
Short Summary

We are a non-profit cultural organization from the city of Ruse, Bulgaria in Eastern Europe. We have successfully organized for 7 years the Green Rock Fest in Ruse - a festival for young rock bands. The idea of the festival is to give a chance to bands at the beginning of their career to perform their music and find friends.

That was the result which we achieved with our Green Rock Fest.(Photo by Tsvetomir Tsvetanov)

The website of the rock festival is www.greenrockfestruse.com


Now we are heading towards a new challenge – to make young people love jazz music and get acquainted with its richness and creative expression.

We would like with your support to give a chance for Halftone Festival to happen in our community. 

Our new project is related to jazz music. Jazz festivals are held in different cities of our country but usually well-known professionals take part in them. 

There is no specialized forum where young followers of jazz music can play. 

That’s why we decided to organize a festival which has the same form as the Green Rock Fest but for jazz music. We hope to attract young people to that kind of music. In that way we will counter the trend promoted by the commercial music companies of music without thinking. Young musicians from our country Bulgaria and abroad will perform at the Halftone festival. To attract audience, we will invite a world famous star.

In order to let this happen we need 12000 USD to cover our costs for organisation and participation of a famous artist.




What We Need & What You Get

Your support will help us to:

-  Cover the costs for the performing artists;

-  Promote the festival to the public and attract audience;

-  Cover the organization costs for sound and light equipment, rent of hall, consumables and recording.

As we are very excited by this campaign, we would like to express our gratitude to you by our perks which we have thought of especially for you:

5 USD – beautiful personalized contributor e-diploma. The diploma will be designed by the young Bulgarian artist Sophia Karakusheva - the author of our logo. It will contain summary collage of the festival, also your name together with our thankful greetings. 

10 USD – the e-poster of the festival. This will be the official poster of the festival signed by the guest musicians in an electronic variant;

25 USD - our special Valentine's perk - invitation for two for the event


35 USD – e-book – “Technical Exercises for Guitar” by the big Bulgarian jazzman and guitarist Alexander Petkov. Alexander Petkov has graduated from The Dresden Conservatory. He is the creator of one of the most important jazz schools in Bulgaria. The compositions , books and albums of Mr Petkov received brilliant reviews by world-class musicians like Robert ( Bob ) Conti , Joe Lano, Joe Diorio , Dusan Bogdanovic and Dale Zdenek ( publisher of Ted Greene and Joe Diorio). 


Its our honour that Mr. Petkov supports our campaign by giving us his e-books!


100 USD + Shipping – Hand-made wooden souvenir mini guitar - 9 centimeter replica of a real guitar by the craft master Dimitar Dancheff. Give the model of your favourite guitar and we will send you the little replica in a beautiful box!


150 USD + Shipping – a cartoon picture of you or your friend or music/sports/cinema etc. idol drawn by the popular artist from our town Ognyan Balkandzhiev. The size of the picture is A4 (8.27 × 11.69 inches). Give us your photos and explain your interests and we will send you an amazing cartoon!


500 USD and more – listed in the poster of the festival as sponsor

Each contributor – listed on the site of the event and on our Facebook page as sponsor (only if the contributor wishes). No matter how much you give, even one dollar, your support is very important to us and we will be thankful!


Unfortunately, in our town expensive tickets are not affordable, as the average monthly salary is about 300 USD. If we manage to cover even a part of the amount through this campaign, we could get the rest through selling tickets at a price considerably lower than its estimated value without your support.

That is why we need this campaign.


The Impact

Young talented people in Bulgaria form bands playing music in various styles. Many of these talents don’t attend music lessons. They rather learn pop and rock from the Internet which is enough to cover some of the hits played by their idols. To play jazz music, they need thorough studies of their instruments but also of music harmony and analysis and that should be done to such grade so that they can not only interpret but also develop their abilities and mind to create their own music while playing on stage

Studying jazz music is very rarely included in the programmes of our schools of arts. Our goal is to give a chance to the young musicians to perform their music and to popularize the beauty and richness of that genre.

Our ambition is to turn the Halftone festival into celebration of young jazz music.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t give your donation now, just come to the festival. It will be held on 24 April 2016!

Dear follower, we would be very happy if you share that campaign and show it to your relatives and friends!

story:
WHAT... IS YOUR NAME?

My name is Vince. Most who don't know me personally or I'm not friends with know me as Vince Vandal. So with that being said: Hi! My name's Vince Elder and I'm from Baltimore, Maryland. If I'm gonna be so bold as to ask for your financial support on a personal project, then it's only fair that you know a little bit about me, right?

First off, I’m most definitely what one would refer to as a ‘nerd.’ I collect graphic tees and Pop! figures (the latter is a new vice for me. Damn you, Harley Quinn), I watch anime and Doctor Who, I’m absolutely obsessed with video games, and I love going to conventions of all sizes. So much, in fact, that I actually ended up working for one, but that’s besides the point.

The point is, my major passion in life above all others is music. I could give up all those other things (even though you would have to drag me kicking and screaming away from my video games) but I definitely couldn’t live without music in my life. Hell, I’m writing this thingright now with earbuds in.

When I was very young I realized I had a talent for musical creation, making rock and hip-hop beats on my old Casio keyboards (you know the ones with that old school ‘Demo’ button? Yeeeeah, I saw you smile) and also re-creating some of my favorite songs and instrumentals. Well, I worked with what I had, anyway.

Over the years I made tons of music for the hell of it, just because it was fun. Then one day while riding around with a good friend of mine, he let me hear a song by some guy named Adam WarRock, and the track was called “Nightcrawlin’.” That was the first time I’d ever heard of what is now known as Nerdcore — music of virtually any style or genre that focuses heavily on ‘nerdy’ foundations, be it comic books, sci-fi, anime, video games and everything in between. Until then I’d only heard your everyday, run-of-the-mill pop music, basically whatever you would hear commonly on the radio in the 90s. Nerdcore opened up a whole other world of music to me, because let’s face it, not all of us can relate to what it’s like being a gangsta.

My first Nerdcore show in 2011: mc chris' Race Wars Tour. Sorry for the potato quality. >_>

Some time passed (I know this is mad long, sorry, I get carried away sometimes… haha) and one day I randomly decided to enter a beat-making contest hosted by NerdyShow. I’d like to say I won the contest (it was actually kinda complicated in the end, to be perfectly honest) but regardless, it led me to actually touch base with some of Nerdcore’s more talented hip-hop artists, the first of which turned out to be Adam WarRock who hit me up and asked me to produce an upcoming project for him. That project turned out to be his sophomore album and my first professional release, “You Dare Call That Thing Human?!?”

So yeah, that’s the long and short of it (mostly long. Actually, all long) and how I came to get into this world I’m in. I’ve gone on to do many, many other projects with a bunch of different, amazing artists (some of which I’ll post throughout this page) and I definitely have no regrets. Every choice I’ve made has gotten me to where I am now.

...Kinda like a TellTale game.

WHAT... IS YOUR QUEST?

Ahhhh okay, I see where this is going. You think you’re slick.

Okay then, let’s do this. My quest is to bring nerdy, pop culture music to the forefront of the music world and let as many people as possible hear how absolutely incredible we can be when faced with a dope beat. You see, what we do is not just Nerdcore — it’s so much more than that.

I’ve been to a ton of shows that prominently feature nerdy music, from relatively high profile artists such as mc chris, Random aka Mega Ran and MC Frontalot, to people who are lower on the ‘known’ scale but no less talented and deserving of recognition such as Insane Ian or The Nerdlucks. All of these people are amazing at what they do, and I want to help showcase their skills. Through the help of various anime conventions, I have hosted a couple shows in the past which were decently received, but I want to branch off and do my own thing — without standing in the shadow of a convention telling me how to do it...

Regarding one of the previously mentioned convention shows I booked, everything was in place and the stage was all set to be what was sure to be a fantastic show. Easily one of the best I've ever had the pleasure of putting together. But unfortunately, as luck would have it this go-round, the show was abruptly canceled not 5-minutes into the first performer's set due to "unforeseen circumstances" (the con's words, not mine), much to the ire of everyone who was excited to see the show -- myself included.

MAN... THAT SUCKS.

It does. Certainly was the first time I've ever had a show canceled on me like that, and in such an unceremonious way, too. That said, there's no use staying salty about what happened. What's past is past, and we must move forward. But that doesn't mean that we just chalk that show-that-wasn't up as a loss. We re-book it! Bigger, and way better than it would have been, while simultaneously giving the fans one hell of an experience. So once more, ladies and gentlemen, I give you the preferred line-up (subject to schedules): 

From left:

  •  PROFESSOR SHYGUY
  •  TRIBE ONE
  •  DR. AWKWARD
  •  MC LARS

Four of the best artists --nerdy or otherwise-- to ever grab a microphone, and the proposed "dream team" for the kickoff show. But no matter what, there WILL be 4-6 incredible performers taking the stage, with the added bonus of a BUNCH of extras to make the show a truly memorable one!

WHAT... IS YOUR PROJECT AND WHAT MAKES IT SO SPECIAL?

The Nerdy Pop Culture Music Festival, or NPC Music Fest for short, is my idea for a musical showcase for nerd music of all styles and genres to come together during a weekend and just have a great time. I make it my priority when working with artists to go above and beyond just booking a standard show. I try my best to make sure they’re having a good time, as well as everyone who took time out of their schedule and money out of their pocket to come see them. They helped bring me into this musical world, so in return I want to show them just how much I truly appreciate it. But I can’t do it the way I would like to without your help.

On the surface, the NPC Music Fest is a day of awesome artists playing equally awesome music. But what I want to do for it in the long run is what makes it really unique. So many times I've heard people talk about other nerd-based festivals or conventions and complain that it would be awesome to attend, but it's clear across the country and their funds/time just won't allow for that kind of travel. So to remedy that, I want the NPC Music Fest to be the first ever (as far as I'm aware) MOBILE nerd music festival. Every year a new artist line-up, every year a new city. I want this to be one of the big shows that people wait all year to go to, then start planning to hit up the next one as soon as it ends. We will bring the music to you so you don't have to worry about pesky things like airfare or booking hotels unless you want to. 

WHAT... IS THE AIRSPEED VELOCITY OF AN UNLADEN SWALLOW?

11 meters per second. Come at me.

WHAT... ARE YOUR PLANS FOR THE FUTURE IF THIS IS SUCCESSFUL?

If the NPC Music Fest gets off the ground and is a resounding success, and I REALLY hope that it is, then of course I want to see it grow. The initial show is currently planned to be held in Virginia Beach, VA. With the following show being in a different state entirely. Every dime that is earned by the show will go back into the show, because ideally I want this to be a yearly thing. Bigger shows, bigger venues (to accommodate the hopefully growing number of attendees), more days… I’m in this for the long haul, and I hope you’re willing to help turn what is currently a vivid dream of mine into what I promise to be an incredible reality.

Thank you all so much, and I hope to see you at the show.

-Vince

TL;DR: Gimme money and we'll make awesome, nerdy, musical magic happen. Trufax.

Risks and challenges

As this is a project that involves multiple people and many yet unknown factors, there may be hiccups and slight delays in the delivery of some rewards. But that's the worst case scenario. I promise that I will make sure everybody receives the things that they pledge for, because it's your money, your faith in me that I can make this happen, and you absolutely deserve it.

11 meters per second. Come at me.

If the NPC Music Fest gets off the ground and is a resounding success, and I REALLY hope that it is, then of course I want to see it grow. The initial show is currently planned to be held in Virginia Beach, VA. With the following show being in a different state entirely. Every dime that is earned by the show will go back into the show, because ideally I want this to be a yearly thing. Bigger shows, bigger venues (to accommodate the hopefully growing number of attendees), more days… I’m in this for the long haul, and I hope you’re willing to help turn what is currently a vivid dream of mine into what I promise to be an incredible reality.
Thank you all so much, and I hope to see you at the show.
-Vince
TL;DR: Gimme money and we'll make awesome, nerdy, musical magic happen. Trufax.



Risks and challengesAs this is a project that involves multiple people and many yet unknown factors, there may be hiccups and slight delays in the delivery of some rewards. But that's the worst case scenario. I promise that I will make sure everybody receives the things that they pledge for, because it's your money, your faith in me that I can make this happen, and you absolutely deserve it.

story:
our music, our magic, our mission

Hidden Soundz takes to the music underground to find the best undiscovered talent and brings it to your computer screen in a new, never before seen music web series by Visual Barz Productions. 

the inspiration

Every other Friday, Hidden Grounds Coffee House opens their doors to artists from all over New Brunswick, NJ for their Biweekly Open Mic Nights and let's us film every second of the action! Hailing from the subversive, sometimes subterranean, and always rockin' music scene of Hub City,  we eventually hope to bring Hidden Soundz to other unexplored and unexposed music venues as the series continues to grow. And we're hoping you can help us expand our exploration!
Hidden Soundz is a digital adventure that takes to you the clandestine musical venues that you might love or might not even know exist to bring you music (or poetry, or comedy, or some other general live artistic joy) that is begging to be heard. We want you to be the first to hear that breakout artist before they got famous. We want you to see magic in the making, see the never before seen, and hear the never before heard!

we could use your help

We're on a musical expedition and we could use your help! These days, a video project such as this is difficult, strenuous, and expensive, but in the end entirely worth it. Our team of expert filmmakers aims for nothing less than the highest quality, visual candy of videos that will transport you to the venue and make you feel like you're sitting in the audience watching the artist play. We want to bring you a unique experience and cultivate community through music. We also have hopes to expand Hidden Soundz as a project, so that we can continue expand the mind, thrill the senses, and open you up to new musical experiences. 

We're hoping to raise $10,000 in order to help us grow our crew in order so we can take this project to new venues and new heights, acquire a better set of equipment so we can continue to bring you stunning video quality, and create buzz so that we can turn this into the enterprise we know it's going to be. And we really want you to be a large part of it. Hidden Soundz is a collaborative production that wouldn't be possible without you and we want to bring you in on the action.


join our adventure:

Here's how you can help us and what you will get in return for any incredibly appreciated contribution. 

$5- We'll extend our warmest thanks and give you a special  thank you shout out in the credits of our latest video.

$15 - You'll receive a high-quality download link to 3 videos and matching MP3s, along with a special thank you shout out in the credits of all of our future videos.

$30 - You'll get all of the previous perks and a postcard signed by one of the artists.

$50 - We'll give you an exclusive print poster signed by 4 of our most popular artists, thank you shout out in the credits,  and a USB with 3 high quality videos and matching MP3s.

$75 - You get a USB, a poster, and a listing as Associate Producer on our credits.

$100 - You'll get a USB, a poster, a goody bag filled with swag, and listing as Associate Producer on our credits.

$200 - A USB! A poster! A swag goody bag! Annnnnddd you'll be listed as EXECUTIVE PRODUCER on our credits.

$300 (or more) - All of the above listed perks as well as a special gift sent directly from us to you to show of our everlasting appreciation.

the impact

This is a chance to see and hear magic and really traverse, transcend, and transform the ways you find new music. We are providing exposure for new local artists who are trying to break out through a digital medium. Its hard and expensive to get a music video made much less marketed these days, and we want to give these more novel artists a chance for their music to be heard, and do a service to the community by providing the exclusive in on authentic sounds from authentic people and places. We want to discover the undiscovered to give yet unknown artists worldwide exposure, help you in cultivating your new music library, and ultimately propagate the growth and connection in today's vast music community. 
We know this is going to be not just a web series, but a musical movement that takes you places you've never seen before featuring artist's you need to hear. 

other ways you can help

Watch our videos! Check out our Hidden Soundz playlist on YouTube to watch the latest and greatest undiscovered artists and hear music that you've never heard before! Feel free, and we hope you will, to like our videos, comment on them, share them, watch them over and over, learn the words, sing along, whatever you like! 

Every little bit helps! We cannot thank you enough and we want to thank you as much as we can.

Live Free and Rock On.

story:
Graham Brazier is one of New Zealand greatest music legends. Graham passed away on the 4th of September 2015. He was loved songwriter and poet and one of New Zealand's most recognised voices. Most will remember him as the enigmatic front man of  legendary band 'Hello Sailor'.  

For the two years previous to his passing, Graham had been coming into Uptown Studios weekly with producer Alan Jansson. Little did we know, they were working on what would become Graham's final legacy to New Zealand Music. 

Only a couple of weeks before Graham's passing, he had completed laying  the tracks.  

We now aim to finish & release his final album.  

Graham Brazier  - "Left Turn at Midnight". 

Those who have heard  songs on the  the album in progress,  feel it is Graham's best work. They are all fantastic new songs. 


ABOUT THE TEAM BEHIND THIS PROJECT:  
KELLY ADDIS: Graham's long term friend of 35 years+  has spear headed the album,  finding a few generous friends, two years ago, to pay to help get the recording process under way.   Graham's dream was to release this solo album and Kelly is determined to fulfil that dream. Kelly's background is in the advertising agency world, where is is an award winner internationally. From having started at Saatchi & Saatchi to being the CEO of the Boiler room which won numerous awards including Australia's  25th fastest growing company in 2005 in Business Review Weekly's Fast 100.   It is these skills that Kelly will put to use when the album is ready to release and his passion that will help to drive the album.
ALAN JANSSON: Alan is one of New Zealand's greatest producers and owner of Uptown Studios.  He too a very long time friend of Graham's,  having produced a single for Graham 'Long Gone for Good' . Alan will be best known to most people as the producer and co-writer of one of New Zealand's most successful songs and album of the same name  OMC 'How Bizarre' along with many  successful music project in a variety of genres including Sister's Underground in the neighbourhood, Sina, 3 The Hardway, mixing and mastering leftshift which won Jazz Album of the Year at the New Zealand music award and Singer Songwriter Aly Cook's two albums , but to name a few.  Alan is also highly successful in the film and TV music scene having won a prestigious New York Tele award in the advertising field. 
ALY COOK: Aly Cook is  Publicist by trade. Aly first met Graham in 1988 whilst working for Auckland Promoters Benny Levin & Mike Corless.  On Aly's latest album 'Horseshoe Rodeo Hotel'  Graham makes a guest appearance & sings backing vocals with Brendan Dugan on the track Western Line & his distinctive harmonica features on her #1 Australian Top 40 Country Hit "Midnight Cowboys".  Aly is a skilled publicist and social media strategist, including having recently done publicity for the Andrea Bocelli Tour down under`,  as well as being an accomplish singer songwriter in her own right. 
RODEO RECORDS: Is a partnership between Aly Cook, Alan Jansson & Kelly Addis with distribution throughout Australia and New Zealand.  The first album is Aly Cook's 'Horseshoe Rodeo Hotel'  with plans in place to complete and release Graham Brazier's 'Left turn at Midnight' and begin pre-production on a new solo album for New Zealand Country Music Legend Brendan Dugan in 2016. 
Please Visit http://igg.me/at/GrahamBrazier 

What We Need & What You Get

We have calculated about US$20,000  to complete the recordings, mix,  master and manufacture the album, Produce a video from archival footage and market the album. 

You can help us achieve this by advance buying the album, buying an exclusive listening at the studio or just donating any amount you wish to help us finish this worthy collection of work.   


Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help

Use the Indiegogo share tools! To share the project on social media.

Please Visit http://igg.me/at/GrahamBrazier

story:
Who is Frontera Bugalu?

Frontera Bugalu is a musical project founded by accordionist and composer Kiko Rodriguez in El Paso, Texas in 2011. Originally established to cover songs by border composers from Texas, it eventually became its own creative project with the release of its debut album in 2011. The band made its name by performing an energetic fusion of border folk music with carribean influences.

"Frontera Buglaú plays raw, edgy socially conscious folk music that's danceable. The norteño influence is immediately evident."

 -SA Current*

The unique fusion of button accordion, harp, piano, and clarinet, the music creates a connection between traditional border music, big city mambo and Caribbean music that swept through Mexico in the 30's. Drawing inspiration from musicians such as Cuban sonero Beny More and mambo master Perez Prado, the result is a unique sound, reflective of the underground “Pachuco” scene of El Paso and Juarez.

*Read full article here


Our Campaign:

This project features two years of compositions, painstakingly put together by writers and later produced in studio. It's lyrics are stories from the Texas borderlands and its music represents the Latino heritage. Despite our growing demographic in the country, very little original Latino music is being produced and made available to the public. The high expense of producing an independent projec, in addition to the lack of resources available to Latino musicians in terms of time and space, are constant obstacles in the attempt to make a musical project reality.



Project cost breakdown:

Frontera Bugalu started recording in late August of 2015 and has already invested thousands of dollars getting the project from the writing process to the studio. We are asking for an additional $6,000 to cover the mixing and mastering process, plus $4,000 to cover the printing and marketing of the release. Mixing and mastering engineers will bring the recording up to a professional sonic level, which is required for music distribution sites and radio play. The artwork and marketing allow the release to have a real chance of garnering regional and national attention. Investing this kind of money into the project will allow us to work with professional studio musicians, mixing and mastering engineers, and art designers, normally not available to low-budget productions. Your support will allow this two-year work-in-progress to have a real chance of being heard. 

If we were not to reach our goal, the money would go towards the mixing and mastering engineering process alone. This in turn will allow the album to be produced at a professional level, allowing us to enter festivals, receive radio play, and access to popular music distributions sites. 


Importance for the Latino community:

It is crucial to support this kind of music at a time where many of the traditions in Latino music, some that took generations to develop, are being lost. Without our folk music being present at our birthdays, anniversaries, weddings, funerals, quinceaneras, etc., we would lose an imperative aspect of our culture that defines us as Latinos and as a people. Supporting musicians who dedicate themselves to these traditions allows the music to continue thriving for future generations. It also allows us to explore and create new songs that include our modern experience as a community. 

On a wider scale, major record labels and commercial producers continue to ignore "Latin" music unless it falls into one of the outdated labels created in the 80's. These labels keep artists from challenging the boundaries and truly exploring their vision. This campaign and other independent releases can broaden the genre to include diverse styles and new sounds.


Our track record: 

As a group, Frontera Bugalu has already self-produced a previous album, and Kiko Rodriguez has released several other recordings over the past 15 years as a musician. The album will also feature various veteran, professional Latino musicians from the SF Bay Area, Los Angeles, and El Paso. The group has already toured in the southwest and counts on grassroots support waiting for a new release.


Overcoming the challenges of the industry:

Your contributions, small or large, will help distribute the burden of an expensive recording process usually reserved for signed or corporate artists. It allows the genre to grow and for the musicians to focus on what they are good at. This kind of musical freedom can only lead to amazing collaborations and creative power among the musicians. 

One of the major risks we are facing is breaking out as independent artist in a world where corporations own all aspects of the music business. Major corporations make it increasingly difficult for independent artists to break out and reach a larger audience by monopolizing everything, from the production process to marketing.

To deal with this issue, we have created a team of dedicated volunteers to help with social media and marketing, recruited musicians and artists to help produce the record, and used the alternative network of touring that has been developed from over a decade of public performances in the U.S. We feel that by tapping into our community we can overcome some of the financial disparities and "blackout" nature of the industry and continue developing a thriving alternative music scene that is hungry for new sounds and ideas. 


Help us by spreading the word!

We appreciate any help from our community, be it monetarily or other. If you can spare a couple dollars for the cause we will be forever thankful. We also appreciate the simple gesture of sharing this page and inviting your friends and family to learn about our cause! Please share our music, videos, and page as anything helps! Thank you. Gracias!

story:
Introduction

Hello everyone, my name is Leonard Francis Farmer III or, Lenny, for short.  But for all intents and purposes here, I’ll be speaking on behalf of my band, Francis Farmer. 

I live in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, and have been working hard as a musician and sound engineer for more than a decade now. Between all the bands I've been involved in over the years, I've completed 3 full length records, and 2 EPs. All of which were self-produced and engineered. (click on these links to listen: Francis Farmer, The Mindsight, UnRaveling)

Intention

I'm creating this campaign in order to help facilitate the recording of my next EP, Rebirth - Chapter 1. The sound will be somewhere between 90s grunge, classic rock and hard rock/metal. I intend to have 3-4 songs complete and ready to released in time for my birthday, January 1st, 2016. 

Passion

I believe very strongly in the songs I've been writing over these last few years. They are soulful and passionate. Simple, yet melodic and musical. They come from the heart and have been the only thing that has helped me keep me sanity through a very dark period in my personal life.  

I know they are the best songs I've written so far, and I genuinely believe that people will connect to them more than anything I've ever done. And this is why I need your help :)

Campaign Target

I'm looking to raise $6,000 to put towards the expenses of this recording. And the closer I get to the target, the more I will be able to do to ensure the quality of the end result.   

You see, making music that sounds as great as the best albums out there requires great performances by great musicians, captured with the help of great engineers on great equipment. Then, it needs the help of more great engineers to mix and master it. And the reality of it is, all of this costs a bunch of money.

And because I also believe strongly in personal growth and development, I really want my next record, Rebirth, to sound nothing short of amazing!  I want it to be the best sounding thing I've ever done.  Onward and upward!

Plan and Budget

- Fly to Vancouver, B.C. Canada, Mid November - $350-400

- Spend 10 days rehearsing/refining songs in various places and rental spaces with studio drummer, Tim Watson (30 hours in paid spaces) - $500

- Spend 2 days recording drums and rhythm guitars in Class A studio Vancouver - $1600-2400

- Studio Drummer Fee (3 songs, discounted friend rate) - $600

- Return flight to Toronto, ON, Canada, Early December - $350-400

- Rehearse/Refine/Compose bass and secondary/lead guitar parts (home studio, no cost) 

- 1 day recording guitars, bass and vocals in Class A studio Toronto $1200

- 2 days mixing at Orange Lounge Studios $2000

- Mastering three songs (Lacquer Channel or Joao Carvalho) $600-850


TOTAL  $7,200-8,350


Clearly, you can now see how money goes quickly when it comes to making music properly!  LOL  You can also see that my budget has me expecting to pay quite a bit out of pocket.  I figure I can't expect anyone else to be willing to pay for this if I'm not.


Rewards/Perks

There won't be any kind of tiered system of rewards for those who donate more than others. For now, I'm keeping it simple.

For all those who donate, I will be giving you a free digital version of the album as soon as it is released (be sure to leave your email in order to collect). I will also be capturing "behind the scenes" type footage throughout the making. I have a number of ideas in this department, but don't want to give them all away :P

Also, if I can make it happen in time, I will be providing you with an advanced version of the first single, before it is officially released to the public.

Lastly, the most important reward you will be receiving will be the knowledge that you are helping someone to continue creating art and living out their dreams!

Why Help and Support?

Let me tell you, it is very difficult to pour your soul out for the world to see and hear. It is indeed therapeutic, but it is an incredibly vulnerable position to put yourself in, and as such it requires a great deal of courage and strength. 

Yes, there is the possibility of love and praise, but there is also the possibility of criticism and hate. But ultimately, you can't let that fear ever stop you. Music and art allow other people to know that they are not alone in this world. That there is at least one more person out there who has felt the same things and lived to talk about it.  

I truly believe music is my calling in life and that is why I have worked so hard towards it. I have also realized that my genuine nature allows others around me to be just as open and genuine. 

A few times in my life now, I've been approached by younger people who told me that watching and hearing me play or listening to my albums has allowed them to believe they can do it too.  Growing in the small town of Gravenhurst, Ontario, there aren't many of us who do this kind of thing. 

Hearing them say that I inspired them to play guitar or sing, is probably the most rewarding thing I've ever experienced in my life. It's those moments that I live for, and keep me inspired to keep making music.

For these reasons, I know that letting my heart shine through music is a true service to the world. Because even if just one more person out there connects to my words and emotions, and it helps them through a dark time, then that makes it all worth while! 

What if the Campaign Target Isn't Reached?

I will be making this EP regardless of the success of this campaign.  My musical experience and engineering background has already allowed me to see many songs and albums through to completion. All done on very minimal budgets.

However, with your help and a little luck, hope and faith, this new EP, Rebirth, will be all that I could've dreamed. And maybe, just maybe, that will let someone else know that it's ok for them to dream too!  


Thank you all so much :)


Leonard F. Farmer III


PS. Maybe you don't have any money to contribute but you still want to help. No worries at all!  You can help by spreading the word about this campaign or maybe some of my other completed works in the links above. It all adds up!  Look for the Indie GoGo share tools. 

Thanks again :)
story_txt:
Introduction
Hello everyone, my name is Leonard Francis Farmer III or, Lenny, for short.  But for all intents and purposes here, I’ll be speaking on behalf of my band, Francis Farmer. I live in Toronto, Ontario, Canada, and have been working hard as a musician and sound engineer for more than a decade now. Between all the bands I've been involved in over the years, I've completed 3 full length records, and 2 EPs. All of which were self-produced and engineered. (click on these links to listen: Francis Farmer, The Mindsight, UnRaveling)IntentionI'm creating this campaign in order to help facilitate the recording of my next EP, Rebirth - Chapter 1. The sound will be somewhere between 90s grunge, classic rock and hard rock/metal. I intend to have 3-4 songs complete and ready to released in time for my birthday, January 1st, 2016. PassionI believe very strongly in the songs I've been writing over these last few years. They are soulful and passionate. Simple, yet melodic and musical. They come from the heart and have been the only thing that has helped me keep me sanity through a very dark period in my personal life.  I know they are the best songs I've written so far, and I genuinely believe that people will connect to them more than anything I've ever done. And this is why I need your help :)Campaign TargetI'm looking to raise $6,000 to put towards the expenses of this recording. And the closer I get to the target, the more I will be able to do to ensure the quality of the end result.   You see, making music that sounds as great as the best albums out there requires great performances by great musicians, captured with the help of great engineers on great equipment. Then, it needs the help of more great engineers to mix and master it. And the reality of it is, all of this costs a bunch of money.And because I also believe strongly in personal growth and development, I really want my next record, Rebirth, to sound nothing short of amazing!  I want it to be the best sounding thing I've ever done.  Onward and upward!Plan and Budget- Fly to Vancouver, B.C. Canada, Mid November - $350-400- Spend 10 days rehearsing/refining songs in various places and rental spaces with studio drummer, Tim Watson (30 hours in paid spaces) - $500- Spend 2 days recording drums and rhythm guitars in Class A studio Vancouver - $1600-2400- Studio Drummer Fee (3 songs, discounted friend rate) - $600- Return flight to Toronto, ON, Canada, Early December - $350-400- Rehearse/Refine/Compose bass and secondary/lead guitar parts (home studio, no cost) - 1 day recording guitars, bass and vocals in Class A studio Toronto $1200- 2 days mixing at Orange Lounge Studios $2000- Mastering three songs (Lacquer Channel or Joao Carvalho) $600-850TOTAL  $7,200-8,350Clearly, you can now see how money goes quickly when it comes to making music properly!  LOL  You can also see that my budget has me expecting to pay quite a bit out of pocket.  I figure I can't expect anyone else to be willing to pay for this if I'm not.Rewards/PerksThere won't be any kind of tiered system of rewards for those who donate more than others. For now, I'm keeping it simple.For all those who donate, I will be giving you a free digital version of the album as soon as it is released (be sure to leave your email in order to collect). I will also be capturing "behind the scenes" type footage throughout the making. I have a number of ideas in this department, but don't want to give them all away :PAlso, if I can make it happen in time, I will be providing you with an advanced version of the first single, before it is officially released to the public.Lastly, the most important reward you will be receiving will be the knowledge that you are helping someone to continue creating art and living out their dreams!Why Help and Support?Let me tell you, it is very difficult to pour your soul out for the world to see and hear. It is indeed therapeutic, but it is an incredibly vulnerable position to put yourself in, and as such it requires a great deal of courage and strength. Yes, there is the possibility of love and praise, but there is also the possibility of criticism and hate. But ultimately, you can't let that fear ever stop you. Music and art allow other people to know that they are not alone in this world. That there is at least one more person out there who has felt the same things and lived to talk about it.  I truly believe music is my calling in life and that is why I have worked so hard towards it. I have also realized that my genuine nature allows others around me to be just as open and genuine. A few times in my life now, I've been approached by younger people who told me that watching and hearing me play or listening to my albums has allowed them to believe they can do it too.  Growing in the small town of Gravenhurst, Ontario, there aren't many of us who do this kind of thing. Hearing them say that I inspired them to play guitar or sing, is probably the most rewarding thing I've ever experienced in my life. It's those moments that I live for, and keep me inspired to keep making music.For these reasons, I know that letting my heart shine through music is a true service to the world. Because even if just one more person out there connects to my words and emotions, and it helps them through a dark time, then that makes it all worth while! What if the Campaign Target Isn't Reached?I will be making this EP regardless of the success of this campaign.  My musical experience and engineering background has already allowed me to see many songs and albums through to completion. All done on very minimal budgets.However, with your help and a little luck, hope and faith, this new EP, Rebirth, will be all that I could've dreamed. And maybe, just maybe, that will let someone else know that it's ok for them to dream too!  Thank you all so much :)Leonard F. Farmer IIIPS. Maybe you don't have any money to contribute but you still want to help. No worries at all!  You can help by spreading the word about this campaign or maybe some of my other completed works in the links above. It all adds up!  Look for the Indie GoGo share tools. Thanks again :)

story:
What's the Story?

"Constellations" is a new powerful chamber opera by composer Efraín Amaya. It's inspired by the struggles of a displaced renowned artist and his family, during times of world conflict, and the power of Art to heal and transcend human suffering. 
The fictional story is based on a period in the life of Joan Miró, the internationally renowned Spanish painter, during his exile in Northern France in the early days of World War II. It was at this time when he started the creation of his well-known series of twenty-three gouaches, the Constellations. These works became a symbol of the power of art in its pursuit of the elevation of the spirit, even at the peak of social crisis and upheaval. 
Amaya composed the music to a story and libretto written by Susana Amundaraín, with whom he has collaborated in previous productions. Both writers empathize with the critical circumstances Miró and his family endured while away from their native country, which struggled under a ruthless dictatorship. This is the first time an opera will be premiered surrounding Miró's work and life.  

The opera in its musical structure consists of three singers, thirteen musicians, and a conductor. This World Premiere performance will be presented in concert form.

“As I reflected on their particular situation back then, I realized it is a current and timeless tale of uncertainty amongst families in search of safer places, and of a better life. We tend to look for the spiritual in the midst of crisis, and we make our faith stronger when a part of ourselves surrenders. Efraín and I have been married for many years now, and we love to go into these collaborations for the sheer pleasure of discovery and creation, but even more, for the excitement of involving more artists, musicians, and of course, all those who are lovers of the arts.” -Susana Amundaraín

Join us in bringing new repertoire to life! ... Here's how we need your help:

Besides having the opportunity to contribute to this century’s American operatic repertoire! your tax-deductible donation will help us finalize production expenses for our (quickly approaching) World Premiere in Philadelphia, PA (USA), and the live recording that would take place to be able to share the work with art & music-lovers worldwide! 

We have secured a wonderful space in Old City Philadelphia, where the premiere will take place: The Neighborhood House Theater, and we are honored to say we have an amazingly talented group of singers and musicians who have embraced our project, and have already committed to perform it for you (read more about them below!). Your support will enable us to pay for:

1. Rehearsal, performance and recording fees for our orchestra musicians; 

2. Stage manager’s fee for performances.

3. Sound engineer’s fee for recording, mixing, mastering.

4. Promotional material.

5. Transportation.

6. Basic insurance for the venue.

7. CD pressing and promotion (graphic design, CD manufacturing, and distribution).

Your support will be greatly appreciated, and your gift will be tax deductible (via our sponsor non-profit organization Arts Crossing). 

When you give towards this project, we would like to say thank you with some exciting rewards, which you can look at in here. If you are unable to donate at this time, please share this campaign with others. Your help is also valuable in spreading the word and helping us achieve our goals.


About the Artists

Efraín Amaya, composer & conductor
American conductor and composer Efraín Amaya was born in Venezuela, where he began his musical training. Continuing his studies in the United States, he earned two Bachelor’s of music degrees in composition and piano from Indiana University, and a Master’s degree in orchestral conducting from Rice University.
Mr. Amaya's compositions have been selected for performance at major international festivals, including the Seattle Symphony's Viva la Música Festival; the V Congreso Iberoamericano de Llíria, Spain, the Festival de Música de Santa Catarina in Brazil, the American Composers Orchestra Festival of Venezuelan Music at Weill Recital Hall in New York; the II Congreso Puertorriqueño de Creación Musical in San Juan among many others.
In 2004, Efraín Amaya received a Fellowship from the Pennsylvania Council on the Arts. He was also a Meet The Composer Composer-in-Residence with Gateway to the Arts, WQED-FM, Renaissance City Wind Music Society and Shaler School District from September of 2001 to September 2004. In 2009 Albany Records label released a CD featuring two of Mr. Amaya’s chamber operas: Clepsydra: An Operatic Installation with 13 Performers and Phantasmagorilla? No! Phantasmagoria, receiving excellent reviews by Pittsburgh, the American Record Guide and Fanfare. His two act opera La Bisbetica, commissioned and performed by International Opera Theater was premiered in August of 2010 in Italy; it was then invited to participate in the Bergamo International Festival of 2011 at Bergamo, Italy.
Mr. Amaya was invited and completed a residency at Yaddo, NY, during the summer of 2012 where he worked on his latest chamber opera Constellations. Since 2007 he’s been the Music Director of TanzTheater André Koslowski. Mr. Amaya has recently joined the faculty at Minot State University and has been named the Music Director for the Minot Symphony Orchestra, starting with the 2015-16 Season.
You may visit Mr. Amaya's Web page at: www.efrainamaya.com

Susana Amundaraín, librettist
Susana Amundarain is a Venezuelan-born American painter, scenic designer, librettist, and one of the founders of Arts Crossing, a recently formed interdisciplinary arts organization. Her multifaceted works, which, as a writer and designer, explore the minds and creative spirit of historical artists and works, have been shown mainly in Latin America and USA. Some of her productions include Explosion of a Memory in Museo de Bellas Artes de Caracas, based on Heiner Müller’s text of the same title, as completion of a Visiting Scholar project in Performance Studies in NYU, New York City. She has received several grants in the USA and Venezuela, including the VAEA (The Venezuelan American Endowment for the Arts) Foundation (NY), The Elizabeth Foundation for the Arts (NY), and an Artist Residency award from Yaddo (NY) among others. Amundaraín has also been awarded, twice, the City First Prize for Scenic Design in Caracas, Venezuela. She has been the scenic designer in residency for TanzTheater André Koslowski since 2005, and is currently an adjunct faculty at the Art Department of Minot State University in North Dakota. Her paintings are included in several museum, corporate, and private collections. She holds an MFA degree from the University of Denver, in Colorado.
Raquel Winnica-Young, mezzo soprano 

Hailed by the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette as a “beautifully voiced singer-actor,” Argentinian Mezzo-soprano Raquel Winnica Young earned a Degree in Vocal Performance from the Colon Opera House in Buenos Aires and an Artist Diploma in Voice from Duquesne University.  
Ms. Winnica Young's career has taken her to concert halls throughout the Americas and Europe. Equally comfortable performing early music, new music and chamber music, she performed in Handel’s La Resurrezione at the Bach Festival in Lausanne, Switzerland, the world-premiere opera Marianita Limenia by Valdo Sciamarella in Buenos Aires, the European tour of the opera Medeamaterial by Pascal Dusapin with Remix Ensemble and presented recitals for Festival Martha Argerich at the Colon Opera House and Festival Llao Llao.
Recent performances include the role of Hermione in the World Premiere of the opera "Winter's Tale" with Quantum Theatre of Pittsburgh, Chatham Baroque and Attack Theater, "Frida" by Xavier Rodriguez, "Speed Dating" by Michael Ching with Microscopic Opera Company, "Messiah" with Chatham Baroque, recitals with The Newberry Consort in Chicago IL and Durango, Mexico as part of the Festival Musica del Virreynato. Past performances include C.P.E. Bach’s Die Israeliten in der Wüste and the title role of Orfeo ed Euridice in Argentina. Closer to home, she sang in Vivaldi’s Gloria at the Strings Music Festival (Colorado), Die Zauberflöte (Third Lady) with Apollo’s Fire in Cleveland, Artemisia (Alindo) with Helios Early Opera in Boston, and Durufle Requiem with Altoona Symphony. With Quantum Theatre she performed the principal role in Astor Piazzolla’s Maria de Buenos Aires and Osvaldo Golijov’sAinadamar, where her portrayal of Federico García Lorca earned her a spot on the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette’s “Best of 2012” lists. Ms. Winnica Young has performed as soloist with the Pittsburgh Camerata, Chatham Baroque, Pittsburgh Baroque Ensemble and the Johnstown (PA) Symphony. She is also a founding member of the Bell'Art Ensemble and the Living Room Chamber Music Project concert series.
A two-time winner of the Pittsburgh Concert Society Major Auditions, Ms. Winnica Young has given recitals in the most prestigious concert halls and Music Festivals in Argentina, Llao Llao Music Festival, Martha Argerich Music Festival, Sans Souci Palace, Ciclo de Conciertos El Rincon, Manuel de Falla and Virrey Liniers Museums Concert Series, closer to home she was the featured artist at the Rodef Shalom Concert Series in Pittsburgh PA (2014/15). Ms.Young participated in EPCASO Summer music program  (Italy), Interharmony Music Festival, Oberlin Baroque Summer Institute, Tafelmusik Baroque Summer Institute, Vancouver Early Music Festival and American Bach Soloists Academy. 
Ms.Winnica Young is Adjunct Faculty in the Voice Department of Indiana University of Pennsylvania. 

Sarah Shafer, soprano

Praised for her “luminous voice” and “intensely expressive interpretations” (The New York Times), and named “remarkable, artistically mature” and “a singer to watch” by Opera News, soprano Sarah Shafer is quickly emerging as a sought-after operatic and concert artist. She recently debuted leading roles in two world-premiere productions with San Francisco Opera; Marco Tutino’s Two Women in the role of Rosetta, and Mary Lennox in The Secret Garden. Other recent roles include Adina in L’Elisir D'Amore with Opera Memphis, Barbarina and the cover role of Susanna in Le nozze di Figaro at the Glyndebourne Festival and the BBC Proms in London’s Royal Albert Hall, Papagena in Opera Philadelphia’s Die Zauberflöte, and Nuria in its production of Osvaldo Golijov’s Ainadamar. Next season she will be appearing as Adina in Opera Philadelphia's production of L'Elisir D'Amore.
A recent graduate of the Curtis Institute of Music, Ms. Shafer’s credits for Curtis Opera Theatre include over 20 productions and a variety of roles such as Pamina in Die Zauberflöte, Almirena in Rinaldo, Giulietta in I Capuleti e i Montecchi, Elizabeth Zimmer in Henze’s Elegy for Young Lovers, Ilia in Idomeneo, Rosina in Il barbiere di Siviglia, Sofia in Il Signor Bruschino, and Mélisande in Impressions of Pelléas. Most recently, she sang the role of Sister Constance in Poulenc’s Dialogues of the Carmelites.
On the concert stage, Ms. Shafer was recently heard in Carnegie Hall as soloist with the New York Choral Society in Mendelssohn's St. Paul. Other recently performed works include Bach's St. John Passion and Mass in B minor, Barber’s Knoxville: Summer of 1915, Poulenc’s Gloria, Lutoslawski’s Chantefleurs et Chantefables, Fauré’s Requiem, Duet for Soprano and Tenor after Tchaikovsky’s Fantasy-Overture Romeo and Juliet, Strauss’ Suite from Der Rosenkavalier, Handel’s Messiah, and Mahler’s Symphony No. 4. Ms. Shafer has appeared as soloist with the Philadelphia Orchestra, the National Orchestra of Mexico, the Nashville Symphony Orchestra, Wroclaw Symphony Orchestra (Poland), the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra, and the Quad City Symphony Orchestra, among others.
An avid recitalist and chamber musician, Ms. Shafer regularly appears with legendary pianist Richard Goode, most recently performing Schumann and Brahms lieder at Carnegie Hall. She has also collaborated with musicians including guitarist Jason Vieaux, and clarinetist Richard Stoltzman. Ms. Shafer was a resident artist at the Marlboro Music Festival for five summers, where she worked with Richard Goode, Mitsuko Uchida, Benita Valente, Sir Thomas Allen, and Martin Isepp. She has also performed at the Mozart and Handel Académie européenne de musique in Aix-en-Provence, France, and most recently at the Bard Music Festival, and Lake Champlain Chamber Music Festival.
A native of State College, PA. Ms. Shafer holds degrees in voice and opera from the Curtis Institute of Music, and is currently based in Philadelphia.

Dan Kempson, baritone

Grammy-nominated baritone Dan Kempson has been praised by theSan Francisco Chronicleas “a singer whose onstage presence was matched by a fluid and handsomely burnished tone.” His 2014-15 also includes a return to Skylight Music Theatreas Peter Stark/Ringmaster in the world premiere of Sucharitkul’s The Snow Dragon, a debut with West Edge Opera as Hannah Before inAs One, and as Stanley Kowalski in A Streetcar Named Desirewith bothTownsend OperaandFresno Grand Opera.  Future engagements include Marcello inLa Bohèmewith both Madison Opera and the Bangor Symphony, Ping inTurandotwith thePacific Symphony, Jacque Brel is Alive and Well in PariswithPerformance Santa Fe, and Florizel in The Winter's Tale, a co-production by Quantum TheatreandChatham Baroque. He was nominated for a 2015 Grammy Award for Best Opera Recording, singing the title role in Milhaud's "L'orestie d'Eschyle".
Dan Kempson’s 2013-14 season included joining the Metropolitan Operafor Nico Muhly’s Two Boys; Carmina Burana with Sacramento Choral Society and Orchestra; as Lieutenant Gordon in Fort Worth Opera’s production of Kevin Puts’ Silent Night; Marcello in La bohème with Savannah Philharmonic; and Glass’ Hydrogen Jukebox with Skylight Music Theatre,and a return to Santa Fe Opera to sing El Dancairo in Carmen. In 2012-13 he sang Figaro in Il barbiere di Siviglia with Shreveport Opera, Anthony in Sweeney Todd  with St. Petersburg Opera, Carmina Burana with the Wichita Symphony Orchestra, and Alwan in the world premiere production of Fairouz’ Sumeida’s Song at the Prototype Festival in New York City. He also joined Santa Fe Opera, covering Count Almaviva in Le nozze di Figaro.
Recent highlights include Belcore in L’elisir d’amore with Mississippi Opera, Figaro in a fully staged production of Il barbiere di Siviglia with the Imperial Symphony Orchestra; Carmina Burana with Syracuse Opera; the baritone role in Philip Glass’ Kepler in his debut with the Spoleto Festival USA; Handel’s Messiah with the Danbury Chamber Orchestra; selections from Haydn’s The Creation with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra; L’elisir d’amore with Caramoor Festival; Brahms’ Requiem with the Erie Philharmonic; Carmina Burana with the Yale Symphony, New Choral Society, and Connecticut Master Chorale; and his debut with Fort Worth Opera in Philip Glass’ Hydrogen Jukebox.
As a Resident Artist with Pittsburgh Opera, Mr. Kempson sang Tarquinius in The Rape of Lucretia, Argante in Rinaldo, Fiorello in Il barbiere di Siviglia, Morales in Carmen, and student matinée performances as Count Almaviva (Le nozze di Figaro) and Figaro in Il barbiere di Siviglia. He also joined the company for its productions of Turandot and Eugene Onegin. As a member of the Merola Opera Program of San Francisco Opera, he performed excerpts as Figaro in Il barbiere di Siviglia, Fluth in The Merry Wives of Windsor, and the title role in Thomas’ Hamlet.
While completing his graduate studies at Manhattan School of Music, Mr. Kempson was seen as Gabriel von Eisenstein in Die Fledermaus, George Jones in Street Scene, and Ronaldo Cabral in John Musto’s Later the Same Evening. Other student performance highlights include Count Almaviva and Carl-Magnus in A Little Night Music with Peabody Opera Theater. He appears in leading roles on recordings of operas by Musto (Albany Records) and Milhaud (NAXOS).
Winner of a 2013 Sullivan Foundation Career Development Grant, Dan has received the Donald Gramm Memorial Award from Santa Fe Opera, as well as prizes from the Gerda Lissner Foundation, Opera Index, Inc, Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, and was a National Semifinalist in the 2009 Eleanor McCollum Competition of the Houston Grand Opera. Mr. Kempson grew up in Wilton, CT.

Chicago IL and Durango, Mexico as part of the Festival Musica del Virreynato.
Past performances include C.P.E. Bach’s Die Israeliten in der Wüste and
the title role of Orfeo ed Euridice in Argentina. Closer to
home, she sang in Vivaldi’s Gloria at the Strings Music Festival
(Colorado), Die Zauberflöte (Third Lady) with Apollo’s Fire in
Cleveland, Artemisia (Alindo) with Helios Early Opera in Boston, and
Durufle Requiem with Altoona Symphony. With Quantum Theatre she
performed the principal role in Astor Piazzolla’s Maria de Buenos
Aires and Osvaldo Golijov’sAinadamar, where her portrayal of Federico
García Lorca earned her a spot on the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette’s “Best of 2012”
lists. Ms. Winnica Young has performed as soloist with the Pittsburgh Camerata,
Chatham Baroque, Pittsburgh Baroque Ensemble and the Johnstown (PA)
Symphony. She is also a founding member of the Bell'Art Ensemble and the
Living Room Chamber Music Project concert series.
A two-time winner of the Pittsburgh Concert Society Major Auditions,
Ms. Winnica Young has given recitals in the most prestigious concert halls
and Music Festivals in Argentina, Llao Llao Music Festival, Martha
Argerich Music Festival, Sans Souci Palace, Ciclo de Conciertos El Rincon,
Manuel de Falla and Virrey Liniers Museums Concert Series, closer to home she
was the featured artist at the Rodef Shalom Concert Series in Pittsburgh PA
(2014/15). Ms.Young participated in EPCASO Summer music program  (Italy),
Interharmony Music Festival, Oberlin Baroque Summer Institute, Tafelmusik
Baroque Summer Institute, Vancouver Early Music Festival and American Bach
Soloists Academy. 
Ms.Winnica Young is Adjunct Faculty in the Voice Department of Indiana
University of Pennsylvania. 

Sarah Shafer, sopranoPraised for her “luminous voice”
and “intensely expressive interpretations” (The New York Times), and
named “remarkable, artistically mature” and “a singer to watch”
by Opera News, soprano Sarah Shafer is quickly emerging as a sought-after
operatic and concert artist. She recently debuted leading roles
in two world-premiere productions with San Francisco Opera; Marco
Tutino’s Two Women in the role of Rosetta, and Mary Lennox
in The Secret Garden. Other recent roles include Adina
in L’Elisir D'Amore with Opera Memphis, Barbarina and the cover
role of Susanna in Le nozze di Figaro at the Glyndebourne Festival
and the BBC Proms in London’s Royal Albert Hall, Papagena in Opera
Philadelphia’s Die Zauberflöte, and Nuria in its production of
Osvaldo Golijov’s Ainadamar. Next season she will be appearing
as Adina in Opera Philadelphia's production of L'Elisir D'Amore.
A recent graduate of the Curtis Institute of Music, Ms. Shafer’s credits for
Curtis Opera Theatre include over 20 productions and a variety of roles such as
Pamina in Die Zauberflöte, Almirena in Rinaldo, Giulietta in I
Capuleti e i Montecchi, Elizabeth Zimmer in Henze’s Elegy for Young
Lovers, Ilia in Idomeneo, Rosina in Il barbiere di Siviglia, Sofia
in Il Signor Bruschino, and Mélisande in Impressions of Pelléas. Most
recently, she sang the role of Sister Constance in Poulenc’s Dialogues of
the Carmelites.
On the concert stage, Ms. Shafer
was recently heard in Carnegie Hall as soloist with the New York Choral Society
in Mendelssohn's St. Paul. Other recently performed works
include Bach's St. John Passion and Mass in B
minor, Barber’s Knoxville: Summer of 1915,
Poulenc’s Gloria, Lutoslawski’s Chantefleurs et Chantefables, Fauré’s Requiem, Duet for Soprano and
Tenor after Tchaikovsky’s Fantasy-Overture Romeo and Juliet,
Strauss’ Suite from Der Rosenkavalier, Handel’s Messiah, and
Mahler’s Symphony No. 4. Ms. Shafer has appeared as soloist with
the Philadelphia Orchestra, the National Orchestra of Mexico, the
Nashville Symphony Orchestra, Wroclaw Symphony Orchestra (Poland), the
Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra, and the Quad City Symphony Orchestra, among
others.
An avid recitalist and chamber musician, Ms. Shafer regularly appears with legendary pianist Richard
Goode, most recently performing Schumann and Brahms lieder at Carnegie
Hall. She has also collaborated with musicians including guitarist Jason
Vieaux, and clarinetist Richard Stoltzman. Ms. Shafer was a resident artist at
the Marlboro Music Festival for five summers, where she worked
with Richard Goode, Mitsuko Uchida, Benita Valente, Sir Thomas Allen,
and Martin Isepp. She has also performed at the Mozart and Handel Académie
européenne de musique in Aix-en-Provence, France, and most recently at the
Bard Music Festival, and Lake Champlain Chamber Music Festival.A native of State College, PA.
Ms. Shafer holds degrees in voice and opera from the Curtis Institute of Music,
and is currently based in Philadelphia.

Dan Kempson, baritoneGrammy-nominated baritone Dan Kempson has
been praised by theSan Francisco Chronicleas
“a singer whose onstage presence was matched by a fluid and handsomely
burnished tone.” His
2014-15 also includes a return to Skylight
Music Theatreas Peter Stark/Ringmaster in the
world premiere of Sucharitkul’s The Snow Dragon, a debut with West Edge Opera as Hannah Before inAs One, and as Stanley Kowalski in A Streetcar Named Desirewith
bothTownsend OperaandFresno Grand Opera.  Future engagements include
Marcello inLa Bohèmewith
both Madison Opera and the Bangor
Symphony, Ping
inTurandotwith thePacific Symphony, Jacque Brel is Alive
and Well in PariswithPerformance Santa Fe, and Florizel in The Winter's Tale, a co-production by Quantum TheatreandChatham Baroque. He was nominated for a 2015
Grammy Award for Best Opera Recording, singing the title role in Milhaud's
"L'orestie d'Eschyle".
Dan Kempson’s 2013-14 season included joining the Metropolitan
Operafor Nico Muhly’s Two Boys; Carmina Burana with Sacramento Choral Society and
Orchestra; as Lieutenant Gordon in Fort Worth Opera’s production of Kevin Puts’ Silent Night; Marcello in La bohème with Savannah Philharmonic; and Glass’ Hydrogen Jukebox with Skylight
Music Theatre,and a return to Santa Fe Opera to sing El Dancairo in Carmen. In 2012-13 he sang Figaro
in Il barbiere di Siviglia with Shreveport
Opera, Anthony in Sweeney Todd  with St. Petersburg Opera, Carmina Burana with the Wichita Symphony Orchestra, and Alwan in the world premiere production of Fairouz’ Sumeida’s Song at the Prototype Festival in New York City. He also joined Santa
Fe Opera, covering Count Almaviva in Le nozze di Figaro.Recent highlights include Belcore in L’elisir d’amore with Mississippi Opera, Figaro in a fully staged production of Il barbiere di Siviglia with the Imperial Symphony
Orchestra; Carmina Burana with Syracuse Opera; the
baritone role in Philip Glass’ Kepler in his debut with the Spoleto Festival USA; Handel’s Messiah with the Danbury Chamber Orchestra; selections from Haydn’s The Creation with the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra; L’elisir d’amore with Caramoor
Festival; Brahms’ Requiem with the Erie Philharmonic; Carmina
Burana with the Yale Symphony, New Choral Society,
and Connecticut Master Chorale; and his debut with Fort
Worth Opera in Philip Glass’ Hydrogen Jukebox.As a
Resident Artist with Pittsburgh Opera, Mr. Kempson sang Tarquinius in The Rape of Lucretia, Argante in Rinaldo,
Fiorello in Il barbiere di Siviglia, Morales in Carmen,
and student matinée performances as Count Almaviva (Le nozze di Figaro)
and Figaro in Il barbiere di Siviglia. He also joined the
company for its productions of Turandot and Eugene Onegin. As a member of the Merola
Opera Program of San Francisco Opera, he performed excerpts as Figaro
in Il barbiere di Siviglia, Fluth in The Merry Wives of
Windsor, and the title role in Thomas’ Hamlet.While
completing his graduate studies at Manhattan
School of Music, Mr. Kempson was seen as Gabriel von Eisenstein
in Die Fledermaus, George Jones in Street Scene,
and Ronaldo Cabral in John Musto’s Later the Same Evening. Other
student performance highlights include Count Almaviva and Carl-Magnus in A
Little Night Music with Peabody
Opera Theater. He appears in leading roles on recordings of operas by
Musto (Albany Records) and Milhaud (NAXOS).Winner
of a 2013 Sullivan Foundation Career Development Grant, Dan has received the
Donald Gramm Memorial Award from Santa Fe Opera, as well as prizes from
the Gerda Lissner Foundation, Opera Index, Inc, Metropolitan Opera National
Council Auditions, and was a National Semifinalist in the 2009 Eleanor
McCollum Competition of the Houston Grand Opera. Mr. Kempson grew up in Wilton,
CT.

story:
Summary

A Great Escape was designed to be exactly what it's named, an escape. It's really all about music and how it has helped so many people over time. Like when you're blasting your earphones in the car because someone won't stop asking what you plan on doing in the future. Or how after having an awful day you're drowning in tears but your favorite song comes on and suddenly everything's right in the world. Music is an escape and live music even more so.

With a strong rock music base, this event (in the summer of 2016) plans to celebrate live music and bring together established, touring artists and up-and-coming acts looking for experience in performing. We believe there is an incredible amount of talent looking for an audience.

All proceeds that aren't used to cover expenses will go towards the Save the Elephants Organization and CARE Organization (the event will be non-profit)!


Funding

Now it's all fun and games when you're talking about awesome stuff, but with big ideas come big prices! Of course as two students in high school wondering how they'll be able to pay for college next year, we have a total combined savings of about $24.22 in our pockets (maybe a piece of lint or gum too), half of which we borrowed from our parents... THIS is where we need your help, in order to make this come true, we are asking for your support to fund our project.  Whether you can afford to help out with $5 to $10,000, any donation is absolutely generous and we will be forever grateful for your help. Of course, we would like to make a festival big enough to give Coachella a run for its money, but no matter what we are able to raise, we are committed to our goal of making our very own music festival in San Diego.


Our Indiegogo funds would go towards:

- Renting a Venue

- Services and Set-Up/Clean-Up

-Artist Expenses

-Logistics Materials

-Legal Aspects

-Security

-Transportation Expenses

-Promotion Material


Risks & Challenges

Finance

Obviously funding! There are always hidden costs when planning an event. The scope of the event will be impacted by the money raised, so it is impossible to say how large the event will be. We plan to produce an event within the budget. If it's not enough to cover the festival's cost, we will transform it into a concert.


Attendance

There is also always the risk of low attendance rates. To avoid this problem, we plan on promoting the event through press, ads, and posters to ensure that the event sells out.


Qualification

“Teenage girls can’t possibly run their own festival!” Not true, but apparently a lot of people seem to think so. In some way we (kind of) understand. We might not have the experience and power of a wealthy 40-year-old in the industry, but what we lack in background, we make for up with passion and commitment. We will have an advisory board made up of female professionals from the event and music industry to guide us in producing the event. The board will include:

Fabi Reyna (founder of She Shreds Magazine)

Michele Fleischli (partner at The Windish Agency)

Molly Logan (founder of School of Doodle)

Through internships, mentorships and seeking professional help, we are devoted to making this a success and showing the world just how much power teen girls really have.

Other Ways You Can Help

If for any reason you can't donate, there is one more way you could help our project. Get the word out and make some noise about the campaign! You can use the Indiegogo share tools. As our first Indiegogo, we might have forgotten to add some details. Feel free to let us know if you have any questions we could clarify.
